description: From basi- +‎ -hyal (from Ancient Greek [Term?] (“the letter upsilon”), from the shape; compare hyoid).

entries.meaning: (anatomy, fish anatomy, vertebrate anatomy) Either of two small bones that form the body of the inverted hyoid arch.
examples: Coburn (1982) used a posterior extension of the basihyal to group many taxa in Notropis (s. l.) (93).
